message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has diabetes. Among the options, Glipizide is a sulfonylurea drug that stimulates insulin secretion, which will increase the levels of C-peptide in the blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. C-peptide is a marker for endogenous insulin production. Among the options, glipizide, which is a sulfonylurea, stimulates insulin secretion and would increase levels of C-peptide in the blood. Insulin and NPH are exogenous sources of insulin, and acarbose inhibits carbohydrate digestion, thus decreasing glucose levels and insulin secretion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest diabetes, which can lead to neuropathy and blurred vision. Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin secretion and can increase C-peptide levels in the blood. Insulin and NPH insulin are both types of insulin and do not increase C-peptide levels, while Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor and does not directly affect insulin secretion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has a high BMI, it suggests that she might have type 2 diabetes. Glipizide stimulates insulin secretion, which leads to an increase in C-peptide levels in the blood, making it the correct option. Insulin and NPH are insulin products that will lower C-peptide levels, and Acarbose is a medication that slows down carbohydrate digestion and absorption but does not affect insulin secretion or C-peptide levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only glipizide stimulates the pancreas to release insulin, which in turn stimulates the secretion of C-peptide. This increase in C-peptide levels can help diagnose type 2 diabetes in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient is presenting with symptoms of type 2 diabetes, we can assume that she has low insulin secretion and/or resistance. Therefore, the drug that would most significantly increase C-peptide levels, which is a marker of insulin secretion, would be a sulfonylurea like glipizide. Insulin itself would also increase C-peptide levels but may not be the best choice for this patient. Acarbose slows down carbohydrate breakdown and may not directly increase insulin secretion. NPH is an intermediate-acting insulin and would not increase C-peptide levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. C-peptide is a protein fragment that is created when insulin is produced and released into the bloodstream. Glipizide is a medication used to treat type 2 diabetes by increasing insulin secretion. Therefore, administration of glipizide would most significantly increase the levels of C-peptide in the blood for this patient. None of the other options are known to increase C-peptide levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin secretion from beta cells in the pancreas. C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production and its levels are used to measure insulin secretion. Therefore, Glipizide would increase the levels of C-peptide in the blood when administered to this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production, and its levels can help assess pancreatic function. Among the options, only glipizide stimulates insulin secretion and therefore increases C-peptide levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest diabetes mellitus, which may lead to decreased C-peptide levels. Among the options, only Glipizide is a sulfonylurea drug that can stimulate insulin secretion and increase C-peptide levels in the blood.
